section.hand:
To my L. Treasuro
r
31 May 90.

page.lettertext:
fol.173r
Belgia: 1590: May
Belgia 1590 31 May To my L. Trea
s
31 May 90
It may please yo
r
L. to bee adv
r
tised
t
I have Rxd by
Persivall
hir
Ma
tyes
l
res
& one fr
o
yo
r
L. & I have made her Ma
ties
excuse both to the
Co
u
-
sell
& to
Co. William
for
t
their l
res
were not aunswered, but for that I am
acquainted w
th
their over suspitious & imagining humo
rs
I feare they will
surmise that there is some matter in that silence that will turn to
their prejudice. Co. William who is now in
Friseland
is sent unto from
hence to declare his opinion for o
r
furder
ceding. The siedge of
Nieu-
meghen
is a lett unto us, for yt is not thought expeident that hir
Ma
tyes
l
res
should be sent into
Groeningh
e
, but when we can p
r
sent
sufficient forces before
e towne of
e Eng
l
nation in spetiall, the better
to concurr in confirmac
o
n of
e letters & to add a greater courage to her
Ma
tyes
friends, who ar thought to be so manie among the inhabitants
as wee are in good hope yf faire meanes faile to winne the towne
force./. Howbeit at this p
nt
almost all
e forces of these countrys
that may bee drawen to
e field are before Nieumeghen, fr
o
whence
they cannot well be spared till their fortificat
o
ns be ended about 3
weekes hence. I have also written to my friends in
Embden
to give
th
e
notice of
e letter to make
e waie more easie, for though I
have had good assistance of Persivall, in respect of his aventures
& travell too & fro, & also otherwise, yet
e minister of Embden
Mentius
& one
Joest van Cleve
in tyme past & Burgm
r
of Groneingen have
bin farr greater instruments: and what oth
r
meanes have bin used to
bring
e matter to this passe it would be to tedious to discourse to yo
r
L.
It was not possible to accomplish her Ma
ties
desire to have yt secretly
caried, for when her Hig
nes
refused to take
e enterprise upon her, there
could nothing bee done w
th
out
e privity & liking of
e C
o
of state, the
States of Frise
, & Co. William. Besides
e opinion is heer
t
the matter
being published, yt hath made a greater p
r
paration among many, w
ch
the
ennemies forces can by no meanes empeache. In my last to yo
r
L. I
signified
t
w
ch
was written to
e Counsell, as well as to my self that
e Spanish Councell of Groeninghen was willed to de
t & that
e towne
was in parle w
th
the states of Frise. Wee are since informed that there
was a publick conference, & hostages delivered but yt concerned only
an agreement, about
e exchange of prisoners: & some were expelled
e towne, but men of meaner qualitie then co
u
sello
rs
. wee are at this
p
nt
adv
r
tised by Co. William
t
Verdugo
hath failed of a late attempt
at hee made to enter
force
e Towne of Groeninghen, & to have put
in garrison, wh
r
too he had many assistants w
th
in
e Towne, w
ch
being notified hath put
e place in a great garboile./ There is at this p
nt
a c
r
tain agreement made between
Co Maurice
& Co. William w
th
consent of
e
Councell of state, that Co. William assisting Co. Maurice w
th
all his forces of
Friseland in
e siege of Nieumeghen he shall after be assisted by Co Maurice
w
th
all
e forces of these quarters in
e enterprise of Groeninghen. At Nieumeghen
there hath bin nothing yet exploited on either side, o
r
fortifications go
forward, w
ch
notw
t
standing
e Enemy hath endevoured to disturb w
th
shott of
great artillery but p
r
vailing nothing yt is supposed he doth but seke to
furnish
e towne w
th
souldiers, & vittailes, & will after passe
e Rhine to
assault some townes of
Guelderland
, therby to divert o
r
forces from Nieumeghen.
There have bin l
res
of
e Enemy lately intercepted writt
e
from
Cullen
to
Zutphen
Deventer
& oth
r
places of w
ch
I send yo
r
L.
e copie of one, the rest con
t
matter
to like effect. The occurrences heer do not signifye as yet of any succours
sent from
e
D . of Parma
to those of
e
Ligue
the souldiers being unwilling to m
r
che
unles they may bee paied for 3 moneths before hand & go w
th
greater forces th
e
e Duke
hath yet appointed, w
ch
wee cannot learne to bee more then 800 horse & 2500 foote
w
ch
many men conjecture this enterprise of Nieumeghen will divert up
o
our selves.
Certain troupes of
Breda
have defeated of late 120 lances of
e Enemy of w
ch
they tooke
30 prisoners & toward 500 head of horses, now that
e Enemy is occupied elsewhere
yt is thought good we should attempt
e revittailing of Breda. w
ch
either succeeded or failed
yesterday. And thus &c. O
r
letters out of
Zeland
report for c
r
tain that
Richardot
is
come to
Bruxelles
& hath comission to offer large conditions of peace./
